greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = lcm_{d|n} tau(d), where tau(d) represents the number of divisors of d (A000005(d)).
comment: A divisibility sequence (cf. Ward link and second formula).
a(n) depends only on prime signature of n (cf. A025487). So a(24) = a(375) since 24 = 2^3*3 and 375 = 3*5^3 both have prime signature (3,1).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Morgan Ward, A note on divisibility sequences, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc., 45 (1939), 334-336.
formula: If n = Product_ prime(i)^e(i), then a(n) = Product_ A003418(e(i)+1).
example: The divisors of 20 are 1, 2, 4, 5, 10 and 20, which have 1, 2, 3, 2, 4 and 6 divisors respectively. The least common multiple of 1, 2, 3, 2, 4 and 6 is 12; therefore, a(20) = 12.
mathematica: lcm[n_] := lcm[n] = LCM @@ Range[n]; a[1] = 1; a[n_] := Times @@ (lcm [Last[#] + 1] & /@ FactorInteger[n]); Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Sep 11 2020 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(d = divisors(n)); lcm(vector(#d, k, numdiv(d[k]))); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jan 23 2015
xref: A250270 gives range of values. A141586 lists numbers n such that a(n) divides n.
results.author: _Matthew Vandermast_, Dec 27 2014
